Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: A comparison of the 1918 influenza pandemic and COVID-19 in Missouri: implications for current mitigation strategies in rural versus urban locations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: This RAPID project will compare epidemic patterns and Missouri residentsâ€™ responses in the 1918 influenza pandemic to those occurring at present during the COVID-19 pandemic, with primary attention paid to urban-rural differences. The research will increase understanding of how life situations in urban versus rural settings affect epidemic disease experiences and will provide knowledge of important community characteristics that put residents at greater risk during the current pandemic. The study will also shed light on which characteristics of a region have been stable over long periods of time and which are aspects of modern life and perhaps more malleable. The research is therefore time-sensitive because the investigators will expeditiously communicate project findings relevant to the current pandemic to the Missouri Department of Health and Senior Services. In addition, this project will provide student training in data collection and first-hand experience in conducting research to help deal with an unforeseen and serious public health event. <br/><br/>A new coronavirus, SARS-CoV-2, to which humans possess little underlying immunity, has been spreading throughout the globe. In this pandemic setting, rural regions may face challenges that are not present in urban areas. As there is currently no vaccine, it is critical to devise effective strategies quickly, to protect rural regions from echo waves of the virus that may circulate over the next few years. The world experienced a similar situation in 1918-19 when a new, lethal strain of influenza began to infect humans. Although there are significant differences between these two pandemics, the viruses have similar modes of transmission and overall impacts on human communities. Understanding the experiences and responses of rural citizens to these two pandemics provides important insights that may lead to new public health strategies that are more tailored to the needs of rural residents during major disease outbreaks. The project involves in-depth comparative analysis of mortality and morbidity patterns during the 1918 influenza pandemic and the present COVID-19 pandemic in the state of Missouri. Analysis will focus on data aggregated at the county level and will determine county characteristics (e.g., population density, number of hospitals, household composition, proximity to large urban area, ethnic composition, mobility patterns) that are associated with death and/or illness rates during the two pandemics. Historical data from the Missouri 1918 influenza pandemic will be examined to identify control strategies used in different counties during the pandemic, determine their effectiveness, and assess whether they would be of use during the present pandemic. This in turn can aid in the development of potential strategies that public health authorities can add to the arsenal already being used in rural counties.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project compared the 1918 influenza pandemic with the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic in the state of Missouri, focusing on differences between urban and rural populations and geographic regions. Specific research questions sought to address the timing and geographic patterns of spread for both pandemics, looking closely at rural-urban relationships and socioeconomic and cultural attributes of the population. To do this work, investigators collected the number of daily deaths by county during the 1918 influenza pandemic and both cases and deaths by day and county during the COVID-19 pandemic. In addition, socioeconomic and demographic data for all counties in the state of Missouri in the early 20th and early 21st centuries were collected. The socioeconomic and demographic data were used to separate the state?s counties into four distinct geographic regions during each of the two time periods, and in addition, a second classification divided the counties into three categories: rural, semi-rural and urban. Pandemic patterns were then examined using each of these two county classification schemes.

The major finding resulting from analyses of data from the 1918 influenza pandemic is the discovery of a large and late wave of flu deaths in Missouri in February of 1920. In the state as a whole, this wave was nearly as large as the main fall 1918 wave of the pandemic. Furthermore, in 25% of the state?s counties it was actually larger than the earlier wave. The influenza death data also indicate that flu mortality was greatest in urban populations over the three-year course of the pandemic. These findings contribute to the body of studies of the 1918 influenza pandemic worldwide and provide additional perspectives on how an epidemic disease resulting from a new pathogen transitions to an endemic disease.

Results from analyses of the COVID-19 data indicate differences in the disease?s impact on urban and rural populations across the course of the pandemic. Early in the pandemic, urban population centers experienced the highest rates of mortality and morbidity from COVID-19. This pattern shifted in late 2020, when rural populations in Missouri experienced higher rates of illness and death and rural counties have continued to be hit harder than urban populations since that time. This finding is important for understanding the disparate timing of COVID-19 impacts in rural and urban locations and will be of use when preparing for future disease outbreaks that have the potential for wide geographic spread.

Comparisons of the 1918 influenza pandemic and COVID-19 has allowed for a better understanding of the use of public health policy, like masking and quarantine orders, over time in the state. It also has demonstrated the continued impact of social determinants of health, such as education and socioeconomic status, on communities during a pandemic. Consistently, communities with lower socioeconomic status, lower access to health care, and lower rates of education experienced higher rates of illness and death during both pandemics in the state.

The broader impacts of this project extend well beyond the increased knowledge of the impact of the 1918 influenza and COVID-19 pandemics in Missouri. This project was able to support and train five graduate students in three academic fields (anthropology, statistics, and public health), as well as provide opportunities for undergraduate students pursuing a variety of majors to earn course credit or volunteer and gain research experience of relevance to today?s world. Both graduate and undergraduate students were trained in research methods in historical epidemiology, public health, and statistics, completed masters? theses or other formal reports, gained required internship credit, and presented posters and papers at local and national conferences. This project brought together senior researchers from several academic disciplines, including anthropology, statistics, mathematics, and medicine, thereby fostering interdisciplinary communication. Investigators also participated in activities that provided health care professionals with continuing education credits needed to maintain their licensure. Finally, investigators on this project participated in the national conversation during the pandemic by giving interviews to many local, regional, national, and international media outlets. During the uncertainty of the early days of the COVID-19 pandemic, their expertise in the 1918 flu was sought after by both health professionals and the general public.
